greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangular array T given by rows: T(n,k)=sum of quotients when Euclidean algorithm acts on n and k; for k=1,2,...,n; n=1,2,3,...; also number of subtraction steps when computing gcd(n,k) using subtractions rather than divisions.
comment: Number of squares in a greedy tiling of an n-by-k rectangle by squares. [_David Radcliffe_, Nov 14 2012]
link: R. J. Mathar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..5050
N. J. A. Sloane, Rows 1 through 100
mathematica: T[n_, k_] := T[n, k] = Which[n < 1 || k < 1, 0, n == k, 1, n < k, T[k, n], True, 1 + T[k, n - k]];
Table[T[n, k], {n, 1, 13}, {k, 1, n}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 29 2020 *)
program: (PARI) tabl(nn) = {for (n=1, nn, for (k=1, n, a = n; b = k; r = 1; s = 0; while (r, q = a\b; r = a - b*q; s += q; a = b; b = r); print1(s, ", ");); print(););} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Aug 17 2015
xref: This is the lower triangular part of the square array in A072030.
results.author: _Clark Kimberling_
